awd_titl_txt: Combinatorial, Computational, and Applied Algebraic Geometry, Seattle 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
The conference "Combinatorial, Computational, and Applied Algebraic Geometry --Seattle 2022 (CCAAGS-22)” will take place 27 June to 1 July 2022 at University of Washington Seattle. Algebraic Geometry is broadly interpreted to be the part of mathematics that studies systems of polynomial equations and inequalities. While Algebraic Geometry has often been considered a solely pure area of mathematics, the community of researchers of CCAAGS-22 promotes its applied and computational nature. Participants of CCAAGS-22 combine Algebraic Geometry with the techniques and methods from symbolic and numeric computation, algorithms, complexity theory, as well as problems motivated by applications in multiple fields. These methods have already seen applications in biology, coding theory, cryptography, combustion, computational geometry, computer graphics, quantum computing, control theory, geometric design, complexity theory, machine learning, nonlinear partial differential equations, optimization, robotics, and statistics, among others. The interaction between algebraic geometry and any of these other disciplines is beneficial for both sides.

This conference brings together researchers and promotes interdisciplinary work in a fast growing area. After the lack of contact during the pandemic, this is a long overdue event. It is particularly useful for junior researchers whose careers strongly depend on making connections and networking. CCAAGS-22 is indeed planned with junior researchers and underrepresented groups as the primary audience we want to attract. For more details see https://sites.google.com/view/ccaaggs-22/home

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In person scientific meetings were suspended due to the COVID19 pandemic. This negatively affected many young researchers who could not discuss their work, nor begin networking for career and research opportunities. As the pandemic eases, it was clear that no amount of ZOOM meetings will replace the need to discuss Mathematics in person and ask questions and initiate collaborations. Mathematics and Science run on people that communicate and debate. The meeting Combinatorial,Computational & Applied Algebraic Geometry 2022 that took place at the University of Washington Seattle, we discuss contemporary research in this very active field in the intersection of Mathematics, Applications, and Computing but we made an special effort to provide a safe space to meet and start the recovery from the years of isolation and lack of networking and collaborations. 

Intelectual Merit: The scientific goal was to showcase a range of applied computational algebraic geometry and combinatorics. We also used the event  to honor a founding mathematician Bernd Sturmfels whose work lies at the intersection of computational, combinatorial and applied Algebraic Geometry and has been an influential mentor to many researchers. We were able to cover a wide range of topics during the event, from the more theoretical to the industrial (e.g., software development). The conference had 22 exciting talks announcing remarkable achievements. All speakers at the conference presented recent research developments. It was exciting to be present at the conference when new techniques were unveiled for the first time to the larger public. One of the highlights was the talk by June Huh (Princeton Univ.), recent winner of the Fields medal at the International Congress of Mathematicians 2022 (this is the highest award in Mathematics). This happened a week before he was elected to the prize!. The talk of June Huh who surveyed his breakthrough results in combinatorics using Hodge theory.June was awarded a Fields Medal in the following week at the ICM. Other highlights include the talk by Melody Chan (Brown Univ.) who showed how some amazing results on moduli spaces come from tropical geometry. Tropical methods translate algebraic problems into polyhedral questions.  Similarly, Greg Blekherman (Georgia Tech) spoke about new ideas in tropical geometry that have gone beyond algebraic sets into domains such as extremal graph theory. Heather Harrington (Oxford Univ.) and Lior Pachter (Caltech) stressed the many opportunities that mathematicians in this field have to contribute to problems from molecular and cellular biology. We had two poster sessions (over 40 posters presented) 

 

Broader Impacts: This conference was one of the first in-person gatherings for many people after COVID started. A generation of researchers was negatively affected. Thus we are very proud of the large human resources impact of our program. We had 165 participants many of them female and minorities (see photos). We brought together many young researchers in this active topic who had several chances to interact with senior members and to hear a great roster of plenary speakers. We paid special attention to students and young researchers, e.g., we had two poster sessions, and one on one meetings with postdocs and made sure senior researchers discuss posters with graduate students.  This program will be remembered for many years by the community as it helped invigorate human resources network after the COVID 19 pandemic stopped all research conferences.  We wish to express our deep gratitude to NSF for the support we received.
